summary: bacterial infections are the most common causes of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbations. if serum inflammatory markers can differentiate bacterial from virus infection in patients with COPD exacerbation requiring emergency department visits. viral infections have been detected in up to 78% of patients with COPD exacerbations. bacteria are considered the major cause of COPD exacerbations. the link of viral infections to COPD has been mentioned in recent studies. all the patients were current smokers or ex-smokers with a smoking history of greater than 20 pack-years. postbronchodilator spirometry prior to the ED visit that demonstrated a ratio of forced expiratory volume in the first second (FEV1) to forced vital capacity (FVC) of 70% was documented. patients with a history of bronchial asthma or with abnormal chest radiographs indicating other respiratory diseases were excluded. a positive bacterial culture was defined as moderate to heavy growth of bacteria in the semiquantitative culture. oropharyngeal swab specimens were inoculated onto MK2, MRC-5, and MDCK cells to isolate the viruses. the cells were incubated at 35°C for 2 weeks.
